Award.AwardTitle: Police Professionalism and Changes in Police Protocols

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Prior research has examined organizational change in policing protocols when police are confronted with public protests. This research has found that police forces rapidly moved from endorsing a model for protest policing that relied on force to stop protests (referred to as "escalated force") to a new model that was based on de-escalating conflict through negotiation (referred to as "negotiated management"). However, this existing work does not adequately: (1) explain how this new alternative developed, (2) examine whether other alternative models developed and competed for adherents; (3) analyze how factors internal to policing, such as police professionalism, affected this process of selection and change; and (4) problematize how organizations are affected by legal mandates. These are critical oversights because major organizational theories have long been able to explain the diffusion of new policies but have not been able to explain where those new policies come from.

This project draws on work from science and technology studies to develop a new perspective on how alternative innovations are created and compete for implementation. Specific hypotheses anticipate: multiple competing alternatives; that alternatives that were consistent with specific elements of police professionalism were more successful competitors; and that the courts did not directly dictate how police forces changed. Data are drawn from quantitative and qualitative content coding of historical police journals and other documents. Analyses map alternatives and their characteristics and track the prevalence of themes identified by the qualitative coding. Findings will advance scholastic understanding of how policing changes over time and how organizations innovate and change. Broader impacts include public distribution of research findings through radio and other media, undergraduate and graduate student training, and scientific gains in understanding organizational change.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Within the study of social movements, many scholars have worked to understand how state and private actors work to control, constrain, or stop protest, referred to in the literature as social movement repression. In the United States, prominent researchers in this area have argued that police forces around the nation underwent a major reorientation to protest in the late 1960s and early 1970s, and with this came the development and deployment of new model practices for handling protest. Specifically, researchers argued that prior to the late 1960s, police departments used a model set of practices referred to as "escalated force" that sought to prevent protest whenever possible and, when not possible, shut them down quickly, primarily through physical force. These same researchers argued that a new model set of practices, referred to as "negotiated management," rose to dominance in the early 1970s, driven by court mandates and pressure from national commission reports, and supported by assistance from the US military. In this new model of protest control, the goal was to limit protest intensity, and the tools used to do this moved away from violence and toward pre-event negotiation.

Embedded within this explanation of the switch from escalated force to negotiated management are several claims about how police agencies, and organizations more generally, change. First, this model assumes that best practices are displaced by singular new entrants into a field, ignoring the possibility of, or at least dismissing the importance of, periods of innovation in which several new partial and/or full alternatives may be developed and gain some level of support by potential adopters. In other words, it assumes that innovations that go on to diffuse are the only options considered, instead of being the historical winners of some larger innovation contest. Second, this model assumes that best practices are highly influenced by coercive legal mandates that both strongly constrain the options of organizations and exert considerable influence on the design of new alternatives. Yet, significant research shows that organizations often enjoy substantial leeway in designing new procedures and constructing compliance. Finally, this explanation assumes police reaction to protest was largely driven by changes in protest and the legal regulation of police action towards protest. However, policing is a complex field that was at that moment itself undergoing transformation as a second drive toward professionalism reshaped many aspects of policing. Therefore, it is unlikely that protest was the sole, or even primary, driver of changes in any particular policing domain, including protest policing.

This study used new theoretical lenses and methods, drawn from research on science and technology, to reconceptualize how innovation takes place, the role of the courts in innovation, and the role of larger trends within policing, such as professionalization, and then to test these new views empirically. Data were collected by manually identifying all articles related to protest, equipment used in controlling protest, groups associated with protest, police understanding of legal rulings, and larger trends in policing such as professionalism published in four police trade journals published across the 1960-1980 period. Each journal represented a different segment of the policing field, ranging from police administrators, to line officers, to federal views on policing, and the academic study of policing (although that journal went out of business in the mid-1970s). Research assistants quantitatively and qualitatively content coded identified articles to uncover the range and prevalence of different themes. Subsequent analysis documented time and journal-specific trends in discussion of these themes, including changes in the problems police saw as related to protest, the groups they associated with protest, and the options they viewed as (un)acceptable in policing protest. Social network analyses were also applied to identify denser patterns of connections between some problems, constituencies, and solutions.

Findings reveal that, as hypothesized, negotiated management was not the only new solution. Indeed, there were a range of potential models for police to choose from in handling protest and instead of settling on a single model, the field developed a repertoire of approaches with various decision-rules about when different models were appropriate. Moreover, the courts did not mandate either specific approaches or the move away from escalated force, but rather set a context in which police had to more explicitly balance the rights of protesters and develop procedures that could be applied in content-neutral ways. Finally, we found that professionalism was important, but did not operate by selecting a singular approach. Instead, professionalism was compatible with many new protest control tactics and strategies, contributing to the growing policing repertoire.

Broader impacts of this research include substantial undergraduate and graduate research training, including for underrepresented students, and a broader understanding of how police departments, and organizations more generally, change. Academic and public-facing publications, such as a research monograph and op-eds, are expected to follow.
